subject: Charles Osgood: The birth of environmentalism
body:

  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday Morning | Face The Nation 






April 20, 2007
Hello, everyone,
Hope 
      you’ve had a good week

The 
      book was called "Silent 
      Spring." It was written by the late Rachel Carson. And to 
      many, it marked the beginning of the growing and increasingly 
      potent "green" movement in the United States, and 
      around the world.
This 
      Sunday Morning – Earth Day – we’ll tell you 
      about the woman who wrote "Silent 
      Spring," and about the legendary CBS 
      Reports documentary that helped put environmentalism 
      on our national agenda some 45 
      years ago.

Remember Lee Iacocca, the legendary auto executive who rose to 
      power at Ford (he created the Mustang), then nursed Chrysler back to 
      profitability after the automaker nearly folded?  Our Anthony Mason 
      will talk to Iacocca, who's 82 
      now, about his former place of employment (Chrysler’s in dire 
      straits once again) and his assessment of where we stand as a 
      nation.

Early 
      next month, Queen Elizabeth travels to Virginia and visits Jamestown, the 
      first English colony in the United States, 
      which marks its 400th 
      anniversary this year. Correspondent Mark Phillips has a history 
      lesson for us this Sunday 
      Morning, told with paintings that capture the manner 
      and the mood of the time.
We’ll, of course, be mindful 
      of events of the week past: Our 
      Martha Teichner asks what comes after Blacksburg, and Ben Stein has a 
      commentary on the dreadful events at Virginia Tech.
We’ll 
      also tell you all about the Oklahoma land rush. Plus, we’ll spend a little time looking 
      into the history of the plastic bag: where it’s been, and where it’s going.

Those 
      stories, and more, this Sunday 
      Morning.
Listen for our trumpet!
